name: K2-239
scenarioDescription:
The K2-239 Exoplanetary System

K2-239 is a star with 0.4 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.36 times its radius. It is located 159.82 light years away from the solar system.

K2-239 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.

K2-239 b

K2-239 b was discovered by the K2 observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 5.24 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, K2-239.

The mass of K2-239 b is 1.21 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-239 b is 1.1 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, K2-239 b is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

K2-239 c

K2-239 c was discovered by the K2 observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.06 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 7.78 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, K2-239.

The mass of K2-239 c is 0.96 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-239 c is 1 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, K2-239 c is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

K2-239 d

K2-239 d was discovered by the K2 observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.07 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 10.12 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, K2-239.

The mass of K2-239 d is 1.21 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-239 d is 1.1 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, K2-239 d is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system K2-239, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by K2.
